Class Translator

  • java.lang.Object
    • Translator

  • public class Translator
extends java.lang.Object
    Translator is a class that deals with the logic of converting from Arabic to Roman Numerals and vice versa. Translator is able to detect if it is Arabic or Roman and also validate Roman Numerals. (Arabic to Roman conversion assumes that Arabic integer is between 1-3999)

      • detectLanguage

        public java.lang.String detectLanguage(char[] typedChars)
        Detects the language of what was entered on the Window side of things. Takes a char array and iterates through that array. Whatever the first language that is found is, that is the precedent set for the rest of the array. As we iterate through the loop we keep checking to that original language we detect. If the language stays the same throughout the array then we have a valid input. If we catch difference the language is marked as "Invalid".
        Parameters:
        typedChars - Char array of the input text area from Window
        Returns:
        String of the detected language from the char array

      • toRoman

        public java.lang.String toRoman(int number)
        Gets an int from Window.inputArea and translates it a Roman numerals. Use of numericChars(int) to get the highest number that the integer is greater than or equal to, as a char. Use of numericInt(int) to do the same thing but to get an integer. If statement checks if the input number equals what is returned from numericInt(int). If the recusive call does not happen and the numerals variable is return. If not there is a recursive call plus the current numerals. A recursive call works great here but can keep getting the highest number available from the input integer and then when it equals the highest number, you can just return back all the Strings that were accumulate, and then a Roman numeral is return.
        Parameters:
        number - Arabic integer
        Returns:
        Roman numerals

      • toArabic

        public java.lang.String toArabic(char[] typedChars)
        Gets a char array from Window.inputArea and translates to an Arabic integer. The method first starts with the call of numeralValidation(char[]) to validate the Roman numerals. If invalid it returns that, but if it is valid the method continues. A for loop iterates through the array and there is an if else that constantly checks for numerals that something like a 4, 9, 40, etc. The reason this check is done is because many Roman numeral pairs have a numeral that is a number above them paired with a number that subtracts the difference, such as 4 is IV. Once the Arabic integer is accumulated it is made a String and returned.
        Parameters:
        typedChars - Roman numerals
        Returns:
        Arabic integer

      • numericChars

        private java.lang.String numericChars(int num)
        Called by toRoman(int) to get the highest numeral that the int is greater than or equal to.
        Parameters:
        num - Arabic integer
        Returns:
        Highest numeral that num is greater than or equal to

      • numericInt

        private int numericInt(int num)

        Parameters:
        num - Arabic integer
        Returns:
        Highest number that num is greater than or equal to

      • numeralValidation

        private boolean numeralValidation(char[] numerals)
        Called by toArabic(char[]) to validate numerals. Two basic rules of Roman numerals are in use here: 1 - V, L, and D can each only happen once; 2 - I, X, C, and M can only happens 3 times (in a row). A switch statement inside a for loop with few count variables is used to achieve this outcome.
        Parameters:
        numerals - Char array of numerals
        Returns:
        Boolean if it is valid or not

      • numeralValue

        private int numeralValue(char numeral)
        Called by toArabic(char[]) to get the numerical value of a numeral.
        Parameters:
        numeral - Roman numeral
        Returns:
        Int value of the numeral
